Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project, Tiospaye in Engineering II, is to increase the number of Native American students graduating from the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology with bachelor's degrees in engineering. "Tiospaye" is a Lakota word meaning extended family; this extended family supports the Native American students in their academic, professional, cultural, and social activities. This engineering extended family includes the scholarship recipients as well as other students, staff, faculty, administrators, alumni, employers, the community, student family members, tribal members, and the tribal college partners, most notably Oglala Lakota College. The financial support of the scholarships combined with one-on-one and one-on-small group contact with the engineering extended family significantly increases the pathways to success for American Indian students in engineering.

Eleven or more scholarships will be awarded to academically talented and financially needy Native American engineering students. In partnership with the ongoing Tiospaye in Science project, this program is: 1) Recruiting academically talented students, who are members of federally recognized tribes, graduates of tribal high schools, or transfers from tribal colleges or universities. These students must demonstrate academic excellence, financial need, and a commitment to an engineering career; 2) Retaining these students in an environment that promotes academic and professional success, while supporting the students socially and in their cultural traditions; and 3) Placing these students in appropriate employment or further education through programs emphasizing career planning and professional options.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The goal of the NSF S-STEM Tiospaye in Engineering II Program at South Dakota School of Mines (SDSMT) was to recruit, retain, and graduate increased numbers of American Indian students in BS engineering degrees. American Indians are under-represented in STEM fields in the United States. South Dakota is home to nine Indian Reservations and American Indians represent ~15% of the population. SDSMT is a specialty STEM public university in the sacred Black Hills. The program provided support in five areas: financial, academic, professional, cultural, and social. Tiospaye is a Lakota word that translates to extended family.

Recruited scholars were required to be academically talented and financial needy - based on unmet need from the FAFSA. Scholars were recruited in a variety of ways including existing students on campus, transfers from tribal colleges, tribal high schools, enrolled tribal members from non-tribal high schools, the South Dakota GEARUP Program, booths at the Black Hills Powwow and the Lakota Nation Invitational. The PI traveled to all nine South Dakota Indian Reservations to a total of 18 high schools, as well as several border high schools and a few high school in neighboring states. The PI traveled to all six tribal colleges in South Dakota, as well as a few in neighboring states. The PI worked closely with Admissions, Registrar, and Financial Aid to recruit and identify eligible scholars.

A total of 38 scholars received funding during the duration of the grant. All were American Indian. Of these scholars, eight were females. In addition to South Dakota, scholars came from Arizona, Colorado, Minnesota, Montana, North Dakota, and Wyoming. Majors represented were Civil Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Geological Engineering, Industrial Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Mining Engineering. In addition to the Principal Investigator (Engineering Professor), the staff included a mentor, student assistants, and tutors. The management team consisted of the Co-PIs, consisting of faculty from Civil Engineering, Humanities, and Metallurgical Engineering. The Tiospaye in Engineering II Program was operated in parallel with our NSF S-STEM Tiospaye in Science Program and succeeded the Tiospaye in Engineering I Program. Scholars were awarded scholarships of up to $8000 per year depending on their FAFSA unmet need. The scholarships were renewable annually if scholars maintained a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5, made adequate progress toward their BS degree, and participated at an acceptable level in program activities. Scholars were required to meet with the PI at least once per month and the program mentor at least weekly. Scholars were required to attend weekly study recitation sessions with the mentor and bi-weekly professional lunch meetings. Topics at these meetings included study skills, testing tips, financial aid, career planning (summer internships, co-operative education, and permanent positions), graduate school opportunities, Native elders, counseling services, summer research opportunities (including NSF REUs), assessment activities, etc. Scholars were required to meet with their academic advisor at least once per semester and register for classes up to two semesters in advance. Scholars were expected to register for cohorted sections in College Algebra, Trigonometry, Calculus I/II/III, College Chemistry, and University Physics courses. The PI and mentor worked with scholars to develop their resume and update them at least once per semester. Scholars were expected to join and participate (at least moderately) in the American Indian Science & Engineering Society (AISES), as well as a professional society in their department. The university provided two Tiospaye study rooms (one for group study and one for quiet study), which were accessible to scholars, not only on school days, but also most evenings and weekends. With the help of donated funds from companies and philanthropists, we were able to provide carpeting, window blinds, white boards, a smartboard projector, a printer (free of print credits), microwave, refrigerator, extra textbooks, and study guides.

The results of our program are as follows. Of the 38 funded students, 26 scholars graduated with BS degrees in engineering, with ten leaving the program and not completing, while two are still in progress.

Overall, our program made significant progress during the duration of the grant. This project has allowed us to develop a solid model and prove that it can work successfully at our university. With the help of Native Elders, we created a successful model and have learned valuable lessons. We have proven that we can recruit high quality students and the students have proven they can be successful. Now we are working to sustain the program with private funding.
